title: 105_s326
content: The Act titled "Abandoned Hardrock Mines Reclamation Act of 1997" requires individuals mining hardrock minerals from patented mining claims to pay a reclamation fee to the Secretary based on a percentage of net proceeds. The fee is determined by the ratio of net proceeds to gross proceeds from production. The reclamation fee for mining hardrock minerals is based on a percentage of net proceeds, determined by the ratio of net proceeds to gross proceeds. Different fee rates apply based on the percentage of gross proceeds, with exemptions for proceeds under $500,000 from mines on single or contiguous patented claims. The reclamation fee for mining hardrock minerals is based on a percentage of net proceeds, with different fee rates applying based on the percentage of gross proceeds. Payments must be made to the Secretary within 60 days after the end of the calendar year. The fees collected are deposited into an Abandoned Minerals Mine Reclamation Fund, and the section is effective for hardrock minerals produced after December 31, 1996. The Abandoned Minerals Mine Reclamation Fund is established under Section 3. The Abandoned Minerals Mine Reclamation Fund is established on the Treasury's books as an interest-bearing fund administered by the Secretary. The Secretary of the Treasury invests excess funds in public debt securities with suitable maturities and interest rates. The Abandoned Minerals Mine Reclamation Fund is used for reclamation and restoration of land and water resources affected by past mineral mining, including areas like abandoned surface mines, milling areas, deep mine entries, and land planting to prevent erosion. It also covers water pollution control from abandoned mine drainage. The Abandoned Minerals Mine Reclamation Fund is used for reclamation and restoration of land and water resources affected by past mineral mining, including areas like abandoned surface mines, milling areas, deep mine entries, and land planting to prevent erosion. It also covers control of surface subsidence due to abandoned deep mines and expenses necessary for reclamation purposes. Eligible areas for reclamation expenditures include lands within States subject to mining laws that were mined or processed for minerals, affected by mining, and abandoned or left unreclaimed before the enactment of this title. The Abandoned Minerals Mine Reclamation Fund is used for reclamation and restoration of land and water resources affected by past mineral mining. Sites designated for remedial action under certain acts are not eligible for expenditures from the Fund. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "gross proceeds" as the value of extracted hardrock minerals that are sold, exchanged, removed from the country, or used in manufacturing or services. "Net proceeds" are gross proceeds minus deductions for extraction, transportation, reduction, refining, sale, marketing, and conversion into money.
